title: Trump pushes aggressive ‘America First’ message to world leaders
text:
poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201909/1888/1155968404_6089046081001_6089052841001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" U.N. General Assembly Trump pushes aggressive ‘America First’ message to world leaders

UNITED NATIONS — President Donald Trump’s “America First” fixation was on stark display on Tuesday in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly, where he boasted of his presidential accomplishments, pushed leaders to adopt his nationalist ideology and threw red meat to his base from the world stage.

“Like my beloved country, each nation represented in this hall, has a cherished history, culture and heritage, that is worth defending and celebrating, and which gives us our singular potential and strength. The free world must embrace its national foundations. It must not attempt to erase them or replace them,” Trump told a silent crowd of world leaders and aides. “The future doesn’t belong to globalists. The future belongs to patriots.”

Story Continued Below

Tuesday’s statement marked the third year in a row that Trump espoused an “America First” foreign policy, the populist message he pledged to embrace on the 2016 campaign trail and that helped fuel his victory.

And though the main themes of his address could have been lifted from one of the often-meandering stump speeches he delivers at raucous campaign-style rallies, Trump spoke deliberately on Tuesday, reading from a teleprompter and appearing to stick to his prepared remarks.

“The future belongs to sovereign and independent nations, who protect their citizens, respect their neighbors and honor the differences that make each country special and unique,” he told a mostly quiet audience — there was no clapping or standing ovation during the address.

poster="https://static.politico.com/45/f0/b02122504d1698e8430e6118eb36/trump-un-fullspeech.png"

He began by touting his military buildup since taking office, though he added that “hopefully it will never have to use this power.”

The president also dedicated a significant chunk of his speech to condemning Iran’s aggression, reiterating his calls for a diplomatic resolution to the crisis in Iran but maintaining that he is prepared to respond with force to defend U.S. interests if necessary.

Trump had stark words for the Islamic Republic, declaring that “as long as Iran’s menacing behavior continues, sanctions will not be lifted,” an apparent reference to the drone strikes on Saudi oil infrastructure that the United States and several allies have blamed on Iran.

“No responsible government should subsidize Iran’s bloodlust,” Trump continued, warning that should Tehran continue lashing out, “Iran’s leader will have turned a proud nation into another precautionary tale.”

But Trump pushed back against critics of his engagement with combative regimes, defending his resistance to meeting hostility with military force by attempting to recast his anti-interventionist streak.

“The United States has never believed in permanent enemies,” he said, pointing to his attempts at diplomacy with Kim Jong Un in North Korea and the Taliban in Afghanistan. “America knows while anyone can make war, only the most courageous can choose peace.”

Vice President Mike Pence and several of Trump’s Cabinet secretaries were seated in the cavernous hall as Trump spoke, including Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and new U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. Kelly Craft. First lady Melania Trump and three of the president’s adult children, Ivanka Trump, Donald Trump Jr., and Tiffany Trump, were also spotted in the chamber.

The president’s annual addresses to the international body have often been the stage for some of his most memorable rhetoric. In his first speech there, Trump nicknamed North Korea’s leader “Rocket Man,” a nickname the president used until the two leaders became friendly amid thawing tensions between their nations. Trump’s second address elicited outright laughter in the chamber hall when he bragged his administration had accomplished more in two years than “almost any administration.”

Trump’s address comes as the shadow of a possible impeachment looms over his presidency back in Washington, revived by allegations that Trump pressured his Ukrainian counterpart to open a corruption investigation into a political rival at the same time he was delaying hundreds of millions in military aid.

He made no mention of the growing controversy in his speech, though Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was present in the hall for Trump’s remarks.

Trump also used the international stage to defend his fixation on border security, railing against “open-border activists who cloak themselves in the rhetoric of social justice” and denouncing what he claimed is a “a growing cottage industry of radical activists and organizations that promote human smuggling” as he framed the issue as an international scourge.

“Mass illegal migration is unfair, unsafe and unsustainable for everyone involved,” he asserted, calling the policies of immigration advocates “cruel and evil.”

“When you undermine border security, you are undermining human rights and dignity. Many of the countries here today are coping with the challenges of uncontrolled migration,” he said. “Each of you has the absolute right to protect your borders. And so, of course, does our country.”

Trump told the audience that he would not accept a “bad” trade deal with China even as the trade war continues, accusing other nations of “acting in bad faith” to exploit international trading rules, and tying the issue to his campaign pledge to return manufacturing jobs to the U.S. “As jobs were outsourced, a small handful grew wealthy at the expense of the middle class,” he said.

Tariffs on U.S. and Chinese goods have begun to act as a drag on the U.S. economy, leaving the president with a major unfulfilled campaign promise as he runs for reelection next year. Still, he said, “at the center of our vision for national renewal is an ambitious campaign to reform international trade,” pledging to reverse what he labeled a “grave economic injustice.”

“Our goal is simple,” Trump said Tuesday. “We want balanced trade that is fair and reciprocal.”

And he didn’t exit the world stage without getting off a few shots at the international community on key issues important to his base. During a riff on the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela, Trump took a swipe at dictator Nicolás Maduro’s socialist regime, an ideological label he’s sought to affix to the Democratic Party’s field of 2020 presidential candidates.

“One of the most serious challenges that we face is the specter of socialism. It’s the wrecker of nations and destroyer of societies,” Trump said, dismissing the ideology as a power grab by “the ruling class.”

He also tied his rant against socialism to social media censorship, a complaint Trump and conservatives have taken up in alleging viewpoint discrimination by tech giants.

“A small number of platforms are acquiring immense power over what we can see and over what we are allowed to say,” he asserted, accusing unnamed “media and economic institutions” of pushing “flat out assaults on our histories, traditions and values.”

“In the United States, my administration has made clear to social media companies that we will uphold the right of free speech. A free society cannot allow social media giants to silence the voices of the people,” he said.

He also provided some red meat by boasting of his split with the international community when it came to abortion rights and guns.

“We are aware that many United Nations projects assert a global right to taxpayer-funded abortion on demand,” Trump said, ripping “global bureaucrats” who, he said, “have absolutely no business attacking the sovereignty of nations that wish to protect innocent life.”

Likewise, he added, “there's no circumstance under which the United States will allow international entities to trample on the rights of our citizens, including the right to self-defense,” announcing that the U.S. would “never” ratify a U.N. arms treaty that gun rights advocates have denounced as infringing upon Second Amendment rights.

He closed by imploring his fellow world leaders to tap into nationalism, telling the audience that “patriots see a nation and its destiny in ways that no one else can.”

“The love of our nations makes the world better for all nations,” he said, issuing a challenge to his counterparts. “Join us in the most fulfilling mission a person could have, the most profound contribution that anyone can make: Lift up your nations and cherish your culture, honor your histories, treasure your citizens, make your country strong and prosperous and righteous, honor the dignity of your people and nothing will be outside of your reach.”
description: Foreign leaders listened closely to Trump’s speech, his third to the multilateral body.
